title: Acute hypoxia drives long-term dysfunctional neutrophil immunity - Nature Immunology
description: Systemic hypoxia is sufficient to induce persistent neutrophil dysfunction in humans, months after acute respiratory distress syndrome or high-altitude conditions. This dysfunction is mediated by loss of the histone modification H3K4me3. In hypoxic mouse models, we show that this reduction in H3K4me3 originates in neutrophil progenitor populations and is a consequence of histone 3 clipping.

Subjects

Systemic hypoxia is sufficient to induce persistent neutrophil dysfunction in humans, months after acute respiratory distress syndrome or high-altitude conditions. This dysfunction is mediated by loss of the histone modification H3K4me3. In hypoxic mouse models, we show that this reduction in H3K4me3 originates in neutrophil progenitor populations and is a consequence of histone 3 clipping.

References

  1. Mirchandani, A. S., Sanchez-Garcia, M. A. & Walmsley, S. R. How oxygenation shapes immune responses: emerging roles for physioxia and pathological hypoxia. Nat. Rev. Immunol. 25, 161–177 (2025). A review addressing the effects of physiological and pathological hypoxia on immune cell function in homeostasis and disease settings.

    Article  CAS  PubMed  Google Scholar 

  2. Kalafati, L., Hatzioannou, A., Hajishengallis, G. & Chavakis, T. The role of neutrophils in trained immunity. Immunol. Rev. 314, 142–157 (2022). A review discussing recent developments in the field of neutrophil-trained immunity and its context-dependent outcomes.

    Article  PubMed  PubMed Central  Google Scholar 

  3. Kwok, I. et al. Combinatorial single-cell analyses of granulocyte-monocyte progenitor heterogeneity reveals an early uni-potent neutrophil progenitor. Immunity 53, 303–318.e5 (2020). This paper reveals the existence of early neutrophil-committed progenitors in mice and humans.

    Article  CAS  PubMed  Google Scholar 

  4. Cheung, P. et al. Repression of CTSG, ELANE and PRTN3-mediated histone H3 proteolytic cleavage promotes monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation. Nat. Immunol. 22, 711–722 (2021). This study reports widespread H3 N terminus cleavage mediated by neutrophil serine proteases that regulates the monocyte-to-macrophage transition.

    Article  CAS  PubMed  PubMed Central  Google Scholar 

  5. Moorlag, S. J. C. F. M. et al. BCG vaccination induces long-term functional reprogramming of human neutrophils. Cell Rep. 33, 108387 (2020). This paper describes trained neutrophil responses associated with increased H3K4me3, months following vaccination with BCG in humans.

    Article  CAS  PubMed  PubMed Central  Google Scholar
